description: Students learn that two letters can represent one sound (digraphs) and that consonant blends maintain individual sounds. This stage introduces CVCC and CCVC word patterns while building advanced phonemic awareness with 4-5 phoneme words.
key_concept: Two letters can work together. Sometimes they make one new sound (digraphs like 'sh'), and sometimes each letter keeps its own sound but blends together (like 'st'). This opens up many more words for reading and spelling.
instructional_focus: Consonant blend fluency maintaining individual sounds
Systematic introduction from simple to complex patterns

science_of_reading_alignment.ehri_phase: Partial to Full Alphabetic - systematic letter-sound correspondence development
science_of_reading_alignment.national_reading_panel: Systematic phonics instruction produces significant benefits through 6th grade
science_of_reading_alignment.adams_principle: Digraphs represent consistent two-letter, one-sound patterns
science_of_reading_alignment.orthographic_mapping: Advanced pattern recognition for complex grapheme-phoneme relationships

metadata.neurological_rationale: First digraph establishes two-letters-one-sound concept (Adams, 1990)

cumulative_decodable_sentences_98_percen: The fish is in the dish. (83% decodable)
I can shut the shop. (60% decodable)
The shed has a fish. (80% decodable)

sound_of_day_integration.brain_science_connection: Digraphs require chunking two letters as single phonological unit
multisensory_cues: Feel air flow through rounded lips
sound_of_day_integration.error_prevention: If confused with /s/, emphasize lip rounding for /sh/

teacher_tips: Watch for: Lip rounding distinguishes /sh/ from /s/
Cue: 'Round your lips like you're shushing someone'
Neurological note: First digraph builds chunking neural pathways
Common error: Students may pronounce /s/ + /h/ separately
error_patterns: Segmentation: Breaking into /s/ + /h/ instead of single /sh/
Substitution: /s/ for /sh/ due to familiar /s/ pattern
Visual: May not recognize sh as single unit

assessment_framework_enhanced.formative_daily: 90% accuracy digraph production as single sound
assessment_framework_enhanced.digraph_understanding: Recognizes two letters make one sound

research_attribution: Adams, M.J. (1990) - /sh/ recommended as first digraph due to clarity
National Reading Panel (2000) - Digraphs essential for advanced phonics
Ehri, L.C. (2005) - Digraph chunking builds orthographic knowledge

metadata.neurological_rationale: Second digraph reinforces two-letters-one-sound concept

cumulative_decodable_sentences_98_percen: I can chop the fish in the dish. (75% decodable)
The rich man can chat. (80% decodable)
Much fish in such a dish. (100% decodable)

sound_of_day_integration.brain_science_connection: Affricate sounds build complex articulation neural patterns
multisensory_cues: Quick tongue tap then air flow
Different from /sh/ - has quick stop first

research_attribution: Adams, M.J. (1990) - /ch/ as second digraph builds pattern recognition
National Reading Panel (2000) - Systematic digraph progression essential
Moats, L.C. (2020) - Affricate sounds require explicit instruction

word_examples.tongue_visibility: Students can see tongue between teeth

multisensory_cues: Mirror work to see tongue placement

research_attribution: Adams, M.J. (1990) - /th/ requires explicit articulation instruction
National Reading Panel (2000) - Dental fricatives build phonemic precision
Moats, L.C. (2020) - Visible articulation supports learning

cumulative_decodable_sentences_98_percen: This fish is with that man. (83% decodable)

metadata.neurological_rationale: Question word pattern essential for comprehension

word_examples.breath_sound: Like blowing out candles with rounded lips

metadata.neurological_rationale: FLOSS rule introduction builds spelling pattern recognition

word_examples.floss_rule: Use ck after short vowels (back, not bac)

multisensory_cues: Two letters for one sound after short vowel
FLOSS rule: double after short vowel

assessment_framework_enhanced.rule_application: Applies FLOSS rule for ck after short vowels

research_attribution: Moats, L.C. (2020) - FLOSS rule essential for spelling development

multisensory_cues: Feel upper teeth on lower lip

research_attribution: Moats, L.C. (2020) - FLOSS rule mastery through multiple examples
National Reading Panel (2000) - Pattern consistency essential
Adams, M.J. (1990) - Spelling rules support reading development
